scene-body.stagedir: Enter, on one side, QUEEN ELIZABETH, DUCHESS OF YORK, and DORSET; on the other, ANNE, Duchess of Gloucester, leading Lady Margaret Plantagenet, CLARENCE's young Daughter

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: Who meets us here? my niece Plantagenet
Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?
Now, for my life, she's wandering to the Tower,
On pure heart's love to greet the tender princes.
Daughter, well met.

speech.speaker: LADY ANNE
speech.line: God give your graces both
A happy and a joyful time of day!

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: As much to you, good sister! Whither away?

speech.speaker: LADY ANNE
speech.line: No farther than the Tower; and, as I guess,
Upon the like devotion as yourselves,
To gratulate the gentle princes there.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Kind sister, thanks: we'll enter all together.
And, in good time, here the lieutenant comes.
Master lieutenant, pray you, by your leave,
How doth the prince, and my young son of York?

speech.speaker: BRAKENBURY
speech.line: Right well, dear madam. By your patience,
I may not suffer you to visit them;
The king hath straitly charged the contrary.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: The king! why, who's that?

speech.speaker: BRAKENBURY
speech.line: I cry you mercy: I mean the lord protector.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: The Lord protect him from that kingly title!
Hath he set bounds betwixt their love and me?
I am their mother; who should keep me from them?

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: I am their fathers mother; I will see them.

speech.speaker: LADY ANNE
speech.line: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother:
Then bring me to their sights; I'll bear thy blame
And take thy office from thee, on my peril.

speech.speaker: BRAKENBURY
speech.line: No, madam, no; I may not leave it so:
I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.

speech.speaker: LORD STANLEY
speech.line: Let me but meet you, ladies, one hour hence,
And I'll salute your grace of York as mother,
And reverend looker on, of two fair queens.
Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster,
There to be crowned Richard's royal queen.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: O, cut my lace in sunder, that my pent heart
May have some scope to beat, or else I swoon
With this dead-killing news!

speech.speaker: LADY ANNE
speech.line: Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news!

speech.speaker: DORSET
speech.line: Be of good cheer: mother, how fares your grace?

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: O Dorset, speak not to me, get thee hence!
Death and destruction dog thee at the heels;
Thy mother's name is ominous to children.
If thou wilt outstrip death, go cross the seas,
And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell
Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughter-house,
Lest thou increase the number of the dead;
And make me die the thrall of Margaret's curse,
Nor mother, wife, nor England's counted queen.

speech.speaker: LORD STANLEY
speech.line: Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.
Take all the swift advantage of the hours;
You shall have letters from me to my son
To meet you on the way, and welcome you.
Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: O ill-dispersing wind of misery!
O my accursed womb, the bed of death!
A cockatrice hast thou hatch'd to the world,
Whose unavoided eye is murderous.

speech.speaker: LORD STANLEY
speech.line: Come, madam, come; I in all haste was sent.

speech.speaker: LADY ANNE
speech.line: And I in all unwillingness will go.
I would to God that the inclusive verge
Of golden metal that must round my brow
Were red-hot steel, to sear me to the brain!
Anointed let me be with deadly venom,
And die, ere men can say, God save the queen!

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory
To feed my humour, wish thyself no harm.

speech.speaker: LADY ANNE
speech.line: No! why? When he that is my husband now
Came to me, as I follow'd Henry's corse,
When scarce the blood was well wash'd from his hands
Which issued from my other angel husband
And that dead saint which then I weeping follow'd;
O, when, I say, I look'd on Richard's face,
This was my wish: 'Be thou,' quoth I, ' accursed,
For making me, so young, so old a widow!
And, when thou wed'st, let sorrow haunt thy bed;
And be thy wife--if any be so mad--
As miserable by the life of thee
As thou hast made me by my dear lord's death!
Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again,
Even in so short a space, my woman's heart
Grossly grew captive to his honey words
And proved the subject of my own soul's curse,
Which ever since hath kept my eyes from rest;
For never yet one hour in his bed
Have I enjoy'd the golden dew of sleep,
But have been waked by his timorous dreams.
Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick;
And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Poor heart, adieu! I pity thy complaining.

speech.speaker: LADY ANNE
speech.line: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Farewell, thou woful welcomer of glory!

speech.speaker: LADY ANNE
speech.line: Adieu, poor soul, that takest thy leave of it!

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: Go thou to Richmond, and good fortune guide thee!
Go thou to Richard, and good angels guard thee!
Go thou to sanctuary, and good thoughts possess thee!
I to my grave, where peace and rest lie with me!
Eighty odd years of sorrow have I seen,
And each hour's joy wrecked with a week of teen.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower.
Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes
Whom envy hath immured within your walls!
Rough cradle for such little pretty ones!
Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow
For tender princes, use my babies well!
So foolish sorrow bids your stones farewell.

scene-body.stagedir: Sennet. Enter KING RICHARD III, in pomp, crowned; BUCKINGHAM, CATESBY, a page, and others

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Stand all apart Cousin of Buckingham!

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: My gracious sovereign?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Give me thy hand.
Thus high, by thy advice
And thy assistance, is King Richard seated;
But shall we wear these honours for a day?
Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: Still live they and for ever may they last!

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: O Buckingham, now do I play the touch,
To try if thou be current gold indeed
Young Edward lives: think now what I would say.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: Say on, my loving lord.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Why, Buckingham, I say, I would be king,

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: Why, so you are, my thrice renowned liege.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Ha! am I king? 'tis so: but Edward lives.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: True, noble prince.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: O bitter consequence,
That Edward still should live! 'True, noble prince!'
Cousin, thou wert not wont to be so dull:
Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead;
And I would have it suddenly perform'd.
What sayest thou? speak suddenly; be brief.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: Your grace may do your pleasure.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Tut, tut, thou art all ice, thy kindness freezeth:
Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: Give me some breath, some little pause, my lord
Before I positively herein:
I will resolve your grace immediately.

speech.speaker: CATESBY
speech.line: The king is angry: see, he bites the lip.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: I will converse with iron-witted fools
And unrespective boys: none are for me
That look into me with considerate eyes:
High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.
Boy!

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Know'st thou not any whom corrupting gold
Would tempt unto a close exploit of death?

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: My lord, I know a discontented gentleman,
Whose humble means match not his haughty mind:
Gold were as good as twenty orators,
And will, no doubt, tempt him to any thing.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: What is his name?

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: I partly know the man: go, call him hither.
The deep-revolving witty Buckingham
No more shall be the neighbour to my counsel:
Hath he so long held out with me untired,
And stops he now for breath?
How now! what news with you?

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: My lord, I hear the Marquis Dorset's fled
To Richmond, in those parts beyond the sea
Where he abides.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Catesby!

speech.speaker: CATESBY
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Rumour it abroad
That Anne, my wife, is sick and like to die:
I will take order for her keeping close.
Inquire me out some mean-born gentleman,
Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter:
The boy is foolish, and I fear not him.
Look, how thou dream'st! I say again, give out
That Anne my wife is sick and like to die:
About it; for it stands me much upon,
To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.
I must be married to my brother's daughter,
Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.
Murder her brothers, and then marry her!
Uncertain way of gain! But I am in
So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin:
Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.
Is thy name Tyrrel?

speech.speaker: TYRREL
speech.line: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Art thou, indeed?

speech.speaker: TYRREL
speech.line: Prove me, my gracious sovereign.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?

speech.speaker: TYRREL
speech.line: Ay, my lord;
But I had rather kill two enemies.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Why, there thou hast it: two deep enemies,
Foes to my rest and my sweet sleep's disturbers
Are they that I would have thee deal upon:
Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

speech.speaker: TYRREL
speech.line: Let me have open means to come to them,
And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel
Go, by this token: rise, and lend thine ear:
There is no more but so: say it is done,
And I will love thee, and prefer thee too.

speech.speaker: TYRREL
speech.line: 'Tis done, my gracious lord.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Shall we hear from thee, Tyrrel, ere we sleep?

speech.speaker: TYRREL
speech.line: Ye shall, my Lord.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: My Lord, I have consider'd in my mind
The late demand that you did sound me in.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Well, let that pass. Dorset is fled to Richmond.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: I hear that news, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Stanley, he is your wife's son well, look to it.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise,
For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd;
The earldom of Hereford and the moveables
The which you promised I should possess.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Stanley, look to your wife; if she convey
Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: What says your highness to my just demand?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: As I remember, Henry the Sixth
Did prophesy that Richmond should be king,
When Richmond was a little peevish boy.
A king, perhaps, perhaps,--

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: My lord!

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: How chance the prophet could not at that time
Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: My lord, your promise for the earldom,--

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Richmond! When last I was at Exeter,
The mayor in courtesy show'd me the castle,
And call'd it Rougemont: at which name I started,
Because a bard of Ireland told me once
I should not live long after I saw Richmond.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: My Lord!

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Ay, what's o'clock?

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: I am thus bold to put your grace in mind
Of what you promised me.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Well, but what's o'clock?

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: Upon the stroke of ten.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Well, let it strike.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: Why let it strike?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Because that, like a Jack, thou keep'st the stroke
Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.
I am not in the giving vein to-day.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: Why, then resolve me whether you will or no.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Tut, tut,
Thou troublest me; am not in the vein.

speech.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
speech.line: Is it even so? rewards he my true service
With such deep contempt made I him king for this?
O, let me think on Hastings, and be gone
To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!

speech.speaker: TYRREL
speech.line: The tyrannous and bloody deed is done.
The most arch of piteous massacre
That ever yet this land was guilty of.
Dighton and Forrest, whom I did suborn
To do this ruthless piece of butchery,
Although they were flesh'd villains, bloody dogs,
Melting with tenderness and kind compassion
Wept like two children in their deaths' sad stories.
'Lo, thus' quoth Dighton, 'lay those tender babes:'
'Thus, thus,' quoth Forrest, 'girdling one another
Within their innocent alabaster arms:
Their lips were four red roses on a stalk,
Which in their summer beauty kiss'd each other.
A book of prayers on their pillow lay;
Which once,' quoth Forrest, 'almost changed my mind;
But O! the devil'--there the villain stopp'd
Whilst Dighton thus told on: 'We smothered
The most replenished sweet work of nature,
That from the prime creation e'er she framed.'
Thus both are gone with conscience and remorse;
They could not speak; and so I left them both,
To bring this tidings to the bloody king.
And here he comes.
All hail, my sovereign liege!

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?

speech.speaker: TYRREL
speech.line: If to have done the thing you gave in charge
Beget your happiness, be happy then,
For it is done, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: But didst thou see them dead?

speech.speaker: TYRREL
speech.line: I did, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?

speech.speaker: TYRREL
speech.line: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them;
But how or in what place I do not know.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after supper,
And thou shalt tell the process of their death.
Meantime, but think how I may do thee good,
And be inheritor of thy desire.
Farewell till soon.
The son of Clarence have I pent up close;
His daughter meanly have I match'd in marriage;
The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom,
And Anne my wife hath bid the world good night.
Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims
At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter,
And, by that knot, looks proudly o'er the crown,
To her I go, a jolly thriving wooer.

speech.speaker: CATESBY
speech.line: My lord!

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Good news or bad, that thou comest in so bluntly?

speech.speaker: CATESBY
speech.line: Bad news, my lord: Ely is fled to Richmond;
And Buckingham, back'd with the hardy Welshmen,
Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near
Than Buckingham and his rash-levied army.
Come, I have heard that fearful commenting
Is leaden servitor to dull delay;
Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary
Then fiery expedition be my wing,
Jove's Mercury, and herald for a king!
Come, muster men: my counsel is my shield;
We must be brief when traitors brave the field.

speech.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
speech.line: So, now prosperity begins to mellow
And drop into the rotten mouth of death.
Here in these confines slily have I lurk'd,
To watch the waning of mine adversaries.
A dire induction am I witness to,
And will to France, hoping the consequence
Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical.
Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret: who comes here?

scene-body.stagedir: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH and the DUCHESS OF YORK

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Ah, my young princes! ah, my tender babes!
My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets!
If yet your gentle souls fly in the air
And be not fix'd in doom perpetual,
Hover about me with your airy wings
And hear your mother's lamentation!

speech.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
speech.line: Hover about her; say, that right for right
Hath dimm'd your infant morn to aged night.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: So many miseries have crazed my voice,
That my woe-wearied tongue is mute and dumb,
Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?

speech.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
speech.line: Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet.
Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs,
And throw them in the entrails of the wolf?
When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?

speech.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
speech.line: When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: Blind sight, dead life, poor mortal living ghost,
Woe's scene, world's shame, grave's due by life usurp'd,
Brief abstract and record of tedious days,
Rest thy unrest on England's lawful earth,
Unlawfully made drunk with innocents' blood!

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: O, that thou wouldst as well afford a grave
As thou canst yield a melancholy seat!
Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.
O, who hath any cause to mourn but I?

speech.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
speech.line: If ancient sorrow be most reverend,
Give mine the benefit of seniory,
And let my woes frown on the upper hand.
If sorrow can admit society,
Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine:
I had an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him;
I had a Harry, till a Richard kill'd him:
Thou hadst an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him;
Thou hadst a Richard, till a Richard killed him;

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him;
I had a Rutland too, thou holp'st to kill him.

speech.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
speech.line: Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard kill'd him.
From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept
A hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death:
That dog, that had his teeth before his eyes,
To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood,
That foul defacer of God's handiwork,
That excellent grand tyrant of the earth,
That reigns in galled eyes of weeping souls,
Thy womb let loose, to chase us to our graves.
O upright, just, and true-disposing God,
How do I thank thee, that this carnal cur
Preys on the issue of his mother's body,
And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: O Harry's wife, triumph not in my woes!
God witness with me, I have wept for thine.

speech.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
speech.line: Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge,
And now I cloy me with beholding it.
Thy Edward he is dead, that stabb'd my Edward:
Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;
Young York he is but boot, because both they
Match not the high perfection of my loss:
Thy Clarence he is dead that kill'd my Edward;
And the beholders of this tragic play,
The adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey,
Untimely smother'd in their dusky graves.
Richard yet lives, hell's black intelligencer,
Only reserved their factor, to buy souls
And send them thither: but at hand, at hand,
Ensues his piteous and unpitied end:
Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray.
To have him suddenly convey'd away.
Cancel his bond of life, dear God, I prey,
That I may live to say, The dog is dead!

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come
That I should wish for thee to help me curse
That bottled spider, that foul bunch-back'd toad!

speech.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
speech.line: I call'd thee then vain flourish of my fortune;
I call'd thee then poor shadow, painted queen;
The presentation of but what I was;
The flattering index of a direful pageant;
One heaved a-high, to be hurl'd down below;
A mother only mock'd with two sweet babes;
A dream of what thou wert, a breath, a bubble,
A sign of dignity, a garish flag,
To be the aim of every dangerous shot,
A queen in jest, only to fill the scene.
Where is thy husband now? where be thy brothers?
Where are thy children? wherein dost thou, joy?
Who sues to thee and cries 'God save the queen'?
Where be the bending peers that flatter'd thee?
Where be the thronging troops that follow'd thee?
Decline all this, and see what now thou art:
For happy wife, a most distressed widow;
For joyful mother, one that wails the name;
For queen, a very caitiff crown'd with care;
For one being sued to, one that humbly sues;
For one that scorn'd at me, now scorn'd of me;
For one being fear'd of all, now fearing one;
For one commanding all, obey'd of none.
Thus hath the course of justice wheel'd about,
And left thee but a very prey to time;
Having no more but thought of what thou wert,
To torture thee the more, being what thou art.
Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not
Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?
Now thy proud neck bears half my burthen'd yoke;
From which even here I slip my weary neck,
And leave the burthen of it all on thee.
Farewell, York's wife, and queen of sad mischance:
These English woes will make me smile in France.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: O thou well skill'd in curses, stay awhile,
And teach me how to curse mine enemies!

speech.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
speech.line: Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days;
Compare dead happiness with living woe;
Think that thy babes were fairer than they were,
And he that slew them fouler than he is:
Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse:
Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: My words are dull; O, quicken them with thine!

speech.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
speech.line: Thy woes will make them sharp, and pierce like mine.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: Why should calamity be full of words?

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Windy attorneys to their client woes,
Airy succeeders of intestate joys,
Poor breathing orators of miseries!
Let them have scope: though what they do impart
Help not all, yet do they ease the heart.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: If so, then be not tongue-tied: go with me.
And in the breath of bitter words let's smother
My damned son, which thy two sweet sons smother'd.
I hear his drum: be copious in exclaims.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter KING RICHARD III, marching, with drums and trumpets

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Who intercepts my expedition?

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: O, she that might have intercepted thee,
By strangling thee in her accursed womb
From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done!

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Hidest thou that forehead with a golden crown,
Where should be graven, if that right were right,
The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown,
And the dire death of my two sons and brothers?
Tell me, thou villain slave, where are my children?

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence?
And little Ned Plantagenet, his son?

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Where is kind Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: A flourish, trumpets! strike alarum, drums!
Let not the heavens hear these tell-tale women
Rail on the Lord's enointed: strike, I say!
Either be patient, and entreat me fair,
Or with the clamorous report of war
Thus will I drown your exclamations.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: Art thou my son?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: Then patiently hear my impatience.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Madam, I have a touch of your condition,
Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: O, let me speak!

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Do then: but I'll not hear.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: I will be mild and gentle in my speech.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: And brief, good mother; for I am in haste.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: Art thou so hasty? I have stay'd for thee,
God knows, in anguish, pain and agony.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: And came I not at last to comfort you?

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: No, by the holy rood, thou know'st it well,
Thou camest on earth to make the earth my hell.
A grievous burthen was thy birth to me;
Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy;
Thy school-days frightful, desperate, wild, and furious,
Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous,
Thy age confirm'd, proud, subdued, bloody,
treacherous,
More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred:
What comfortable hour canst thou name,
That ever graced me in thy company?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Faith, none, but Humphrey Hour, that call'd
your grace
To breakfast once forth of my company.
If I be so disgracious in your sight,
Let me march on, and not offend your grace.
Strike the drum.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: I prithee, hear me speak.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: You speak too bitterly.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: Hear me a word;
For I shall never speak to thee again.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: So.

speech.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
speech.line: Either thou wilt die, by God's just ordinance,
Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror,
Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish
And never look upon thy face again.
Therefore take with thee my most heavy curse;
Which, in the day of battle, tire thee more
Than all the complete armour that thou wear'st!
My prayers on the adverse party fight;
And there the little souls of Edward's children
Whisper the spirits of thine enemies
And promise them success and victory.
Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end;
Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse
Abides in me; I say amen to all.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Stay, madam; I must speak a word with you.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: I have no more sons of the royal blood
For thee to murder: for my daughters, Richard,
They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens;
And therefore level not to hit their lives.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: You have a daughter call'd Elizabeth,
Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: And must she die for this? O, let her live,
And I'll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty;
Slander myself as false to Edward's bed;
Throw over her the veil of infamy:
So she may live unscarr'd of bleeding slaughter,
I will confess she was not Edward's daughter.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Wrong not her birth, she is of royal blood.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: To save her life, I'll say she is not so.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Her life is only safest in her birth.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: And only in that safety died her brothers.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: No, to their lives bad friends were contrary.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: True, when avoided grace makes destiny:
My babes were destined to a fairer death,
If grace had bless'd thee with a fairer life.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Cousins, indeed; and by their uncle cozen'd
Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life.
Whose hand soever lanced their tender hearts,
Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction:
No doubt the murderous knife was dull and blunt
Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart,
To revel in the entrails of my lambs.
But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame,
My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys
Till that my nails were anchor'd in thine eyes;
And I, in such a desperate bay of death,
Like a poor bark, of sails and tackling reft,
Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise
And dangerous success of bloody wars,
As I intend more good to you and yours,
Than ever you or yours were by me wrong'd!

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: What good is cover'd with the face of heaven,
To be discover'd, that can do me good?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: No, to the dignity and height of honour
The high imperial type of this earth's glory.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Flatter my sorrows with report of it;
Tell me what state, what dignity, what honour,
Canst thou demise to any child of mine?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Even all I have; yea, and myself and all,
Will I withal endow a child of thine;
So in the Lethe of thy angry soul
Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs
Which thou supposest I have done to thee.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Be brief, lest that be process of thy kindness
Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Then know, that from my soul I love thy daughter.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: What do you think?

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul:
So from thy soul's love didst thou love her brothers;
And from my heart's love I do thank thee for it.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning:
I mean, that with my soul I love thy daughter,
And mean to make her queen of England.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Say then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Even he that makes her queen who should be else?

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: What, thou?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: I, even I: what think you of it, madam?

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: How canst thou woo her?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: That would I learn of you,
As one that are best acquainted with her humour.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: And wilt thou learn of me?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Madam, with all my heart.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Send to her, by the man that slew her brothers,
A pair of bleeding-hearts; thereon engrave
Edward and York; then haply she will weep:
Therefore present to her--as sometime Margaret
Did to thy father, steep'd in Rutland's blood,--
A handkerchief; which, say to her, did drain
The purple sap from her sweet brother's body
And bid her dry her weeping eyes therewith.
If this inducement force her not to love,
Send her a story of thy noble acts;
Tell her thou madest away her uncle Clarence,
Her uncle Rivers; yea, and, for her sake,
Madest quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Come, come, you mock me; this is not the way
To win our daughter.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: There is no other way
Unless thou couldst put on some other shape,
And not be Richard that hath done all this.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Say that I did all this for love of her.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee,
Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Look, what is done cannot be now amended:
Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes,
Which after hours give leisure to repent.
If I did take the kingdom from your sons,
To make amends, Ill give it to your daughter.
If I have kill'd the issue of your womb,
To quicken your increase, I will beget
Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter
A grandam's name is little less in love
Than is the doting title of a mother;
They are as children but one step below,
Even of your mettle, of your very blood;
Of an one pain, save for a night of groans
Endured of her, for whom you bid like sorrow.
Your children were vexation to your youth,
But mine shall be a comfort to your age.
The loss you have is but a son being king,
And by that loss your daughter is made queen.
I cannot make you what amends I would,
Therefore accept such kindness as I can.
Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul
Leads discontented steps in foreign soil,
This fair alliance quickly shall call home
To high promotions and great dignity:
The king, that calls your beauteous daughter wife.
Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother;
Again shall you be mother to a king,
And all the ruins of distressful times
Repair'd with double riches of content.
What! we have many goodly days to see:
The liquid drops of tears that you have shed
Shall come again, transform'd to orient pearl,
Advantaging their loan with interest
Of ten times double gain of happiness.
Go, then my mother, to thy daughter go
Make bold her bashful years with your experience;
Prepare her ears to hear a wooer's tale
Put in her tender heart the aspiring flame
Of golden sovereignty; acquaint the princess
With the sweet silent hours of marriage joys
And when this arm of mine hath chastised
The petty rebel, dull-brain'd Buckingham,
Bound with triumphant garlands will I come
And lead thy daughter to a conqueror's bed;
To whom I will retail my conquest won,
And she shall be sole victress, Caesar's Caesar.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: What were I best to say? her father's brother
Would be her lord? or shall I say, her uncle?
Or, he that slew her brothers and her uncles?
Under what title shall I woo for thee,
That God, the law, my honour and her love,
Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Infer fair England's peace by this alliance.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Which she shall purchase with still lasting war.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Say that the king, which may command, entreats.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: That at her hands which the king's King forbids.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Say, she shall be a high and mighty queen.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: To wail the tide, as her mother doth.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Say, I will love her everlastingly.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: But how long shall that title 'ever' last?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Sweetly in force unto her fair life's end.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: But how long fairly shall her sweet lie last?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: So long as heaven and nature lengthens it.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: So long as hell and Richard likes of it.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Say, I, her sovereign, am her subject love.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Then in plain terms tell her my loving tale.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: O no, my reasons are too deep and dead;
Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their grave.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Now, by my George, my garter, and my crown,--

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Profaned, dishonour'd, and the third usurp'd.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: I swear--

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: By nothing; for this is no oath:
The George, profaned, hath lost his holy honour;
The garter, blemish'd, pawn'd his knightly virtue;
The crown, usurp'd, disgraced his kingly glory.
if something thou wilt swear to be believed,
Swear then by something that thou hast not wrong'd.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Now, by the world--

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: 'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: My father's death--

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Thy life hath that dishonour'd.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Then, by myself--

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Thyself thyself misusest.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Why then, by God--

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: God's wrong is most of all.
If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him,
The unity the king thy brother made
Had not been broken, nor my brother slain:
If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him,
The imperial metal, circling now thy brow,
Had graced the tender temples of my child,
And both the princes had been breathing here,
Which now, two tender playfellows to dust,
Thy broken faith hath made a prey for worms.
What canst thou swear by now?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: The time to come.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: That thou hast wronged in the time o'erpast;
For I myself have many tears to wash
Hereafter time, for time past wrong'd by thee.
The children live, whose parents thou hast
slaughter'd,
Ungovern'd youth, to wail it in their age;
The parents live, whose children thou hast butcher'd,
Old wither'd plants, to wail it with their age.
Swear not by time to come; for that thou hast
Misused ere used, by time misused o'erpast.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: As I intend to prosper and repent,
So thrive I in my dangerous attempt
Of hostile arms! myself myself confound!
Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours!
Day, yield me not thy light; nor, night, thy rest!
Be opposite all planets of good luck
To my proceedings, if, with pure heart's love,
Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts,
I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter!
In her consists my happiness and thine;
Without her, follows to this land and me,
To thee, herself, and many a Christian soul,
Death, desolation, ruin and decay:
It cannot be avoided but by this;
It will not be avoided but by this.
Therefore, good mother,--I must can you so--
Be the attorney of my love to her:
Plead what I will be, not what I have been;
Not my deserts, but what I will deserve:
Urge the necessity and state of times,
And be not peevish-fond in great designs.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Ay, if the devil tempt thee to do good.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Shall I forget myself to be myself?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Ay, if yourself's remembrance wrong yourself.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: But thou didst kill my children.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: But in your daughter's womb I bury them:
Where in that nest of spicery they shall breed
Selves of themselves, to your recomforture.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: And be a happy mother by the deed.

speech.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
speech.line: I go. Write to me very shortly.
And you shall understand from me her mind.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Bear her my true love's kiss; and so, farewell.
Relenting fool, and shallow, changing woman!
How now! what news?

speech.speaker: RATCLIFF
speech.line: My gracious sovereign, on the western coast
Rideth a puissant navy; to the shore
Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends,
Unarm'd, and unresolved to beat them back:
'Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral;
And there they hull, expecting but the aid
Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Some light-foot friend post to the Duke of Norfolk:
Ratcliff, thyself, or Catesby; where is he?

speech.speaker: CATESBY
speech.line: Here, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Fly to the duke:
Post thou to Salisbury
When thou comest thither--
Dull, unmindful villain,
Why stand'st thou still, and go'st not to the duke?

speech.speaker: CATESBY
speech.line: First, mighty sovereign, let me know your mind,
What from your grace I shall deliver to him.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: O, true, good Catesby: bid him levy straight
The greatest strength and power he can make,
And meet me presently at Salisbury.

speech.speaker: CATESBY
speech.line: I go.

speech.speaker: RATCLIFF
speech.line: What is't your highness' pleasure I shall do at
Salisbury?

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?

speech.speaker: RATCLIFF
speech.line: Your highness told me I should post before.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: My mind is changed, sir, my mind is changed.
How now, what news with you?

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: None good, my lord, to please you with the hearing;
Nor none so bad, but it may well be told.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Hoyday, a riddle! neither good nor bad!
Why dost thou run so many mile about,
When thou mayst tell thy tale a nearer way?
Once more, what news?

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: Richmond is on the seas.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: There let him sink, and be the seas on him!
White-liver'd runagate, what doth he there?

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: I know not, mighty sovereign, but by guess.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Well, sir, as you guess, as you guess?

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: Stirr'd up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Ely,
He makes for England, there to claim the crown.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Is the chair empty? is the sword unsway'd?
Is the king dead? the empire unpossess'd?
What heir of York is there alive but we?
And who is England's king but great York's heir?
Then, tell me, what doth he upon the sea?

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: Unless for that, my liege, I cannot guess.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Unless for that he comes to be your liege,
You cannot guess wherefore the Welshman comes.
Thou wilt revolt, and fly to him, I fear.

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: No, mighty liege; therefore mistrust me not.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Where is thy power, then, to beat him back?
Where are thy tenants and thy followers?
Are they not now upon the western shore.
Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships!

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: No, my good lord, my friends are in the north.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Cold friends to Richard: what do they in the north,
When they should serve their sovereign in the west?

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: They have not been commanded, mighty sovereign:
Please it your majesty to give me leave,
I'll muster up my friends, and meet your grace
Where and what time your majesty shall please.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Ay, ay. thou wouldst be gone to join with Richmond:
I will not trust you, sir.

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: Most mighty sovereign,
You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful:
I never was nor never will be false.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Well,
Go muster men; but, hear you, leave behind
Your son, George Stanley: look your faith be firm.
Or else his head's assurance is but frail.

speech.speaker: STANLEY
speech.line: So deal with him as I prove true to you.

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire,
As I by friends am well advertised,
Sir Edward Courtney, and the haughty prelate
Bishop of Exeter, his brother there,
With many more confederates, are in arms.

speech.speaker: Second Messenger
speech.line: My liege, in Kent the Guildfords are in arms;
And every hour more competitors
Flock to their aid, and still their power increaseth.

speech.speaker: Third Messenger
speech.line: My lord, the army of the Duke of Buckingham--

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Out on you, owls! nothing but songs of death?
Take that, until thou bring me better news.

speech.speaker: Third Messenger
speech.line: The news I have to tell your majesty
Is, that by sudden floods and fall of waters,
Buckingham's army is dispersed and scatter'd;
And he himself wander'd away alone,
No man knows whither.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: I cry thee mercy:
There is my purse to cure that blow of thine.
Hath any well-advised friend proclaim'd
Reward to him that brings the traitor in?

speech.speaker: Third Messenger
speech.line: Such proclamation hath been made, my liege.

speech.speaker: Fourth Messenger
speech.line: Sir Thomas Lovel and Lord Marquis Dorset,
'Tis said, my liege, in Yorkshire are in arms.
Yet this good comfort bring I to your grace,
The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest:
Richmond, in Yorkshire, sent out a boat
Unto the shore, to ask those on the banks
If they were his assistants, yea or no;
Who answer'd him, they came from Buckingham.
Upon his party: he, mistrusting them,
Hoisted sail and made away for Brittany.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: March on, march on, since we are up in arms;
If not to fight with foreign enemies,
Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.

speech.speaker: CATESBY
speech.line: My liege, the Duke of Buckingham is taken;
That is the best news: that the Earl of Richmond
Is with a mighty power landed at Milford,
Is colder tidings, yet they must be told.

speech.speaker: KING RICHARD III
speech.line: Away towards Salisbury! while we reason here,
A royal battle might be won and lost
Some one take order Buckingham be brought
To Salisbury; the rest march on with me.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter DERBY and SIR CHRISTOPHER URSWICK

speech.speaker: DERBY
speech.line: Sir Christopher, tell Richmond this from me:
That in the sty of this most bloody boar
My son George Stanley is frank'd up in hold:
If I revolt, off goes young George's head;
The fear of that withholds my present aid.
But, tell me, where is princely Richmond now?

speech.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
speech.line: At Pembroke, or at Harford-west, in Wales.

speech.speaker: DERBY
speech.line: What men of name resort to him?

speech.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
speech.line: Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier;
Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley;
Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt,
And Rice ap Thomas with a valiant crew;
And many more of noble fame and worth:
And towards London they do bend their course,
If by the way they be not fought withal.

speech.speaker: DERBY
speech.line: Return unto thy lord; commend me to him:
Tell him the queen hath heartily consented
He shall espouse Elizabeth her daughter.
These letters will resolve him of my mind. Farewell.
